navis package¶

Subpackages¶

  • navis.messages package

Submodules¶

navis.api module¶

Navis API Client for interacting with the robot control server.

This module provides a simple, high-level Python interface for controlling and monitoring robots connected to the Navis server. It handles HTTP requests for sending commands and fetching state, and includes a real-time visualization tool and a “plug-and-play” real-time connection manager.

class navis.api.ServerAddress(host: str = 'localhost', port: int = 4321)[source]¶

Bases: object

A dataclass to hold server connection details.

host: str = 'localhost'¶
port: int = 4321¶
navis.api.set_server_address(host: str, port: int = 4321)[source]¶

Programmatically sets the server address for all subsequent API calls.

navis.api.get_rest_api_uri() → str[source]¶

Constructs the base URI for the REST API.

navis.api.get_websocket_uri(robot_id: str) → str[source]¶

Constructs the full WebSocket URI for a specific robot.

class navis.api.RobotConnection(robot_id: str, robot_type: str, robot_object: object)[source]¶

Bases: object

Manages a persistent real-time connection to a robot on the server.

This class provides a “plug-and-play” interface. You provide an object that represents your robot’s logic, and this class handles the WebSocket connection, registration, sending state updates, and receiving commands in the background.

The provided robot_object must have two methods: - get_measurement(): Must return a Protobuf Measurement object. - handle_command(cmd): Will be called with a Protobuf MoveCommand object.

Parameters:

  • robot_id (str) – The unique ID of the robot.

  • robot_type (str) – The type string (e.g., “DifferentialDriveRobot”).

  • robot_object (object) – An instance of your robot’s logic class.

start()[source]¶

Starts the robot connection loop in the background.

stop()[source]¶

Stops the robot connection loop.

navis.api.get_state(robot_id: str) → dict[source]¶
navis.api.move(robot_id: str, linear_vel: float = 0.0, angular_vel: float = 0.0)[source]¶

navis.robot module¶

Data classes and registry for representing and managing robot state.

class navis.robot.BaseRobot(robot_id: str, x: float = 0.0, y: float = 0.0, theta: float = 0.0, last_measurement: ~robot_comms_pb2.Measurement | None = None, ws: ~starlette.websockets.WebSocket | None = None, lock: ~asyncio.locks.Lock = <factory>)[source]¶

Bases: ABC

Abstract base class representing a generic robot.

This dataclass defines a common interface and shared attributes for all robot types managed by the server. It includes basic pose information, server-side connection details, and an abstract method for state updates.

robot_id¶

The unique identifier for the robot.

Type:

str

x¶

The robot’s x-coordinate in a global frame. Defaults to 0.0.

Type:

float

y¶

The robot’s y-coordinate in a global frame. Defaults to 0.0.

Type:

float

theta¶

The robot’s orientation (angle) in a global frame. Defaults to 0.0.

Type:

float

last_measurement¶

The last raw Protobuf measurement message received from the robot. Defaults to None.

Type:

Optional[Measurement]

ws¶

The active WebSocket connection for this robot, if currently connected. Defaults to None.

Type:

Optional[WebSocket]

lock¶

An asyncio lock to ensure thread-safe access to the robot’s attributes, as multiple server tasks might access them.

Type:

asyncio.Lock

robot_id: str¶
x: float = 0.0¶
y: float = 0.0¶
theta: float = 0.0¶
last_measurement: Measurement | None = None¶
ws: WebSocket | None = None¶
lock: Lock¶
abstractmethod update_from_proto(meas: Measurement)[source]¶

Abstract method to update the robot’s state from a Protobuf message.

Parameters:

meas (Measurement) – The Protobuf message containing new state data.

class navis.robot.DifferentialDriveRobot(robot_id: str, x: float = 0.0, y: float = 0.0, theta: float = 0.0, last_measurement: ~robot_comms_pb2.Measurement | None = None, ws: ~starlette.websockets.WebSocket | None = None, lock: ~asyncio.locks.Lock = <factory>, v: float = 0.0, omega: float = 0.0, wheel_velocities: ~typing.List[float] = <factory>, wheel_base: float = 0.15, time_step: float = 0.1)[source]¶

Bases: BaseRobot

Represents a two-wheeled differential drive robot.

Inherits from BaseRobot and adds state and properties specific to a differential drive configuration, such as linear and angular velocities.

v¶

The robot’s forward linear velocity. Defaults to 0.0.

Type:

float

omega¶

The robot’s angular velocity. Defaults to 0.0.

Type:

float

wheel_velocities¶

The individual velocities of the left and right wheels. Defaults to [0.0, 0.0].

Type:

List[float]

wheel_base¶

The distance between the two wheels. Defaults to 0.15.

Type:

float

time_step¶

The simulation or control time step. Defaults to 0.1.

Type:

float

v: float = 0.0¶
omega: float = 0.0¶
wheel_velocities: List[float]¶
wheel_base: float = 0.15¶
time_step: float = 0.1¶
update_from_proto(meas: Measurement)[source]¶

Updates the robot’s state from a Protobuf Measurement message.

Parameters:

meas (Measurement) – The Protobuf message from the robot.

set_velocities(v: float, omega: float)[source]¶

Sets target velocities and calculates the required wheel speeds.

This method applies inverse kinematics to translate a desired body velocity (linear v and angular omega) into the necessary velocities for the left and right wheels to achieve that motion.

Parameters:

  • v (float) – The target linear velocity.

  • omega (float) – The target angular velocity.

navis.server module¶

FastAPI server for managing and communicating with robots over WebSockets. It uses Protobuf for message serialization over the WebSocket connection. Install navis and run navis-server in the command line.

navis.server.lifespan(app: FastAPI)[source]¶
async navis.server.robot_ws(websocket: WebSocket, robot_id: str)[source]¶

Manages the WebSocket lifecycle for a single robot client.

This function handles the initial registration of a robot, listens for incoming measurement data, and ensures that any queued commands are sent upon connection. It also manages graceful disconnection and error handling.

The communication protocol is as follows: 1. Client connects to the WebSocket. 2. Client sends a ClientToServer Protobuf message containing a Register payload. 3. Server validates the registration and adds the robot to the registry. 4. Client periodically sends ClientToServer messages with Measurement payloads. 5. Server can send MoveCommand Protobuf messages to the client at any time.

Parameters:

  • websocket (WebSocket) – The WebSocket connection instance provided by FastAPI.

  • robot_id (str) – The unique identifier for the robot, passed from the URL path.

Raises:

ValueError – If the first message is not a valid registration message, if the robot_id in the registration message does not match the URL, or if the robot_type is unknown.

async navis.server.move_robot(command: dict)[source]¶

Receives a move command and sends it to a specified robot.

This endpoint accepts a JSON payload to control a robot’s movement. If the target robot is currently connected via WebSocket, the command is sent immediately. If the robot is not connected, the command is queued and will be sent the next time it connects.

Parameters:

command (dict) – A dictionary containing the command parameters. Expected keys: ‘robot_id’ (str), ‘v’ (float, optional), ‘omega’ (float, optional).

Returns:

A confirmation of the action taken (sent or queued) or an

error response with an appropriate HTTP status code (400 for bad request, 404 for robot not found).

Return type:

JSONResponse

async navis.server.get_robot_state(robot_id: str)[source]¶

Retrieves the last reported state for a specific robot.

Queries the in-memory registry for a robot’s last known measurement data. The data is returned as a JSON object.

Parameters:

robot_id (str) – The unique identifier of the robot, from the URL path.

Returns:

A JSON object containing the latest measurement data

(e.g., position, velocity) converted from its Protobuf format. Returns a 404 error if the robot ID is not found in the registry.

Return type:

JSONResponse

navis.server.main()[source]¶

Main function to run the Uvicorn server, callable by the entry point.

navis.visualizer module¶

Command-line script for real-time robot visualization.

This script uses the Navis API to fetch a robot’s state and displays it using Matplotlib. It is designed to be run from the command line after the ‘navis’ package is installed.

Example Usage:

  • Visualize robot_001 connecting to the server at localhost:8000

>>> navis-visualizer --robot-id robot_001

  • Visualize a different robot on a remote server

>>> navis-visualizer --robot-id robot_002 --host 192.168.1.100 --port 9999
navis.visualizer.state_fetcher_loop(robot_id: str, interval_s: float)[source]¶

Continuously fetches state in a background thread.

navis.visualizer.main()[source]¶

Parses arguments, sets up the plot, and runs the animation.

Module contents¶

Navis Robotics Communication API

This package provides a high-level Python interface for controlling and monitoring robots connected to the Navis server.

To get started, configure the server address:

import navis navis.set_server_address(“your_server_ip”)

Then, use the API functions to interact with your robots:

state = navis.get_state(“robot_001”) navis.move(“robot_001”, linear_vel=0.5)

navis.set_server_address(host: str, port: int = 4321)[source]¶

Programmatically sets the server address for all subsequent API calls.

Constructs the base URI for the REST API.

class navis.RobotConnection(robot_id: str, robot_type: str, robot_object: object)[source]¶

Bases: object

Manages a persistent real-time connection to a robot on the server.

This class provides a “plug-and-play” interface. You provide an object that represents your robot’s logic, and this class handles the WebSocket connection, registration, sending state updates, and receiving commands in the background.

The provided robot_object must have two methods: - get_measurement(): Must return a Protobuf Measurement object. - handle_command(cmd): Will be called with a Protobuf MoveCommand object.

Parameters:

  • robot_id (str) – The unique ID of the robot.

  • robot_type (str) – The type string (e.g., “DifferentialDriveRobot”).

  • robot_object (object) – An instance of your robot’s logic class.

start()[source]¶

Starts the robot connection loop in the background.

stop()[source]¶

Stops the robot connection loop.
